artist: Artist: Tsukioka Yoshitoshi; Author: Sumida Ryōko; Publisher: Fukushimaya Tashichi
catalogue_raissonne: Keyes, Courage and Silence (1982), no. 116.4; Iwakiri, Yoshitoshi (2014), p. 20 no. 19, p. 289.
creditline: The Mary Griggs Burke Endowment Fund established by the Mary Livingston Griggs and Mary Griggs Burke Foundation, gifts of various donors, by exchange, and gift of Edmond Freis in memory of his parents, Rose and Leon Freis
description: monkey with arms spread and mouth open, falling off a cliff in front of a waterfall; group of monkeys on top of cliff in URC look on
medium: Woodblock print (nishiki-e); ink and color on paper
portfolio: From A Modern Journey to the West (Tsūzoku saiyūki 通俗西遊記)
signed: 一魁斎芳年画 {Ikkaisai Yoshitoshi ga}
text: The Monkey King Sun Wukong (Jap. Son Gokū) is one of the leading characters in the 16th-century Chinese novel The Journey to the West (Xiyouji). Born from a divine stone egg he is endowed with intelligence and magical powers. In search for spiritual understanding he takes off on a journey but is imprisoned for bringing havoc upon the Celestial Palace of the Jade Emperor. Eventually he will be released to accompany the Buddhist monk Xuanzang on his journey west to India. This print shows a group of monkeys observing a waterfall. One brave monkey jumps to penetrate the waterfall so he discovers its source and will be crowned Monkey King.
title: A monkey jumps into a waterfall
